qualitative_analysis.article_title: A Pricing Framework for Software-as-a-Service
qualitative_analysis.quote: SaaS is outsourced software, meaning that both technology infrastructure and management - hardware, software and professional services - are contracted out to software vendors
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes SaaS as a service model where infrastructure and management are outsourced, highlighting the service delivery and remote hosting characteristics of the business model.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: A Pricing Framework for Software-as-a-Service
qualitative_analysis.quote: The second challenge comes from the diversity of SaaS clients, among which small and medium enterprises have been the most aggressive adopters. Likewise, large corporations are equally attracted to the idea of acquiring software services on demand
qualitative_analysis.justification: Identifies two distinct customer segments (SMEs and large corporations) and emphasizes the on-demand nature of SaaS delivery model.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: A Pricing Framework for Software-as-a-Service
qualitative_analysis.quote: clients are charged through recurring subscription fees on a pay-as-you-go basis
qualitative_analysis.justification: Explicitly describes the pricing strategy combining subscription model with usage-based payment approach.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Selection of the Proper Revenue and Pricing Model for SaaS
qualitative_analysis.quote: The network operators operate the platform and deliver games to players' set-top boxes or to PCs through their broadband network... It is based on revenue sharing between three players, the content owner, a portal, and ourselves –all sharing the content revenue. If the content is [equivalent to] five dollars, we share it so that there are two dollars for the portal, and two dollars for the content owner, and one for us
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes a platform-based gaming business model with complex revenue sharing among multiple ecosystem partners (network operators, content owners, and portals).

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Selection of the Proper Revenue and Pricing Model for SaaS
qualitative_analysis.quote: Cloud computing can be divided roughly into three service layers... (i) Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS), which provides computation and storage capacity, (ii) Platform as a Service (PaaS), which provides software development tools plus an application execution environment, and (iii) Software as a Service (SaaS), which provides applications on top of PaaS and IaaS
qualitative_analysis.justification: Defines the cloud computing stack and positions SaaS within the broader cloud infrastructure ecosystem.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Transition to the Cloud: A Vendor Perspective
qualitative_analysis.quote: The second segment is small and medium size business with less than 1000 employees, where ERP Co works closely with their partners, all what they refer to as value added resellers. Here, all the sales go through ERP Co partners, which could be platinum partners that only work for ERP Co and build their services around ERP Co products, or gold partners that mainly work with ERP Co but also engage with other businesses, or smaller partners and resellers that represent ERP Co or their products in micro markets and local markets around the country
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes a complex partner ecosystem with different tiers of resellers serving the SME market, highlighting the importance of ecosystem management in software business models.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Transition to the Cloud: A Vendor Perspective
qualitative_analysis.quote: up to 50% of the initial ERP Co license fees do go to VAR
qualitative_analysis.justification: Shows significant revenue sharing with partners in a traditional licensing model, demonstrating partner compensation strategy.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Transition to the Cloud: A Vendor Perspective
qualitative_analysis.quote: the platinum partners collaborate with ERP Co to achieve "synergistic integration," in which new products and services are developed by the partners based on the ERP Co system, and both sides reinforce each other and achieve value co-creation
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes value co-creation through synergistic partnerships, characteristic of platform business models where ecosystem partners collaborate to create mutual value.

qualitative_analysis.quote: offering a platform or an ecosystem in which your business can grow together with others that depend on yours

qualitative_analysis.justification: Shows power asymmetries in platform ecosystems where infrastructure providers have significant bargaining power over content providers.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Designing business models for cloud platforms
qualitative_analysis.quote: five possible customer segments: (1) individual developers...student groups or start-ups; (2) ISVs who develop and consume C&A on the platform; (3) system integrators (SIs) such as IT consultancies, who do this for their customers; (4) platform customers...enterprises that use PaaS solutions as a private cloud; and (5) the actual end user, meaning consumers of C&A
qualitative_analysis.justification: Defines five distinct customer segments in PaaS business models, showing the complexity of multi-sided platform markets.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Designing business models for cloud platforms
qualitative_analysis.quote: relationships with complementors rely on well-defined rules, IPR regulations, and collaboration models
qualitative_analysis.justification: Emphasizes the importance of governance mechanisms in managing platform ecosystems and complementor relationships.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Business Models for Cloud Computing: Experiences from Developing Modeling & Simulation as a Service Applications in Industry
qualitative_analysis.quote: Within the CloudSME project there are four stakeholder groups...End-users: At one end of this chain, there exist the end-user companies from the manufacturing and engineering sector...Simulation software providers...Cloud platform providers...Cloud resource providers
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes the full cloud value chain for vertical SaaS targeting SMEs in manufacturing, from infrastructure to end users.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Business Models for Cloud Computing: Experiences from Developing Modeling & Simulation as a Service Applications in Industry
qualitative_analysis.quote: The commercial relationship is therefore EUROBIOS using ASCOMP's software that uses the CSSP developed by multiple stakeholders that uses (say) Amazon cloud resources
qualitative_analysis.justification: Shows the complex multi-layer ecosystem relationships in cloud-based vertical applications with multiple intermediaries.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: A Study on a Decentralized SaaS Business Model
qualitative_analysis.quote: HQ may have some brand products and responsible for their global advertisement, R&D, and training
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes a decentralized SaaS model where headquarters provides brand and R&D while local servers operate independently.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: A Study on a Decentralized SaaS Business Model
qualitative_analysis.quote: local servers will get some supports from their HQ and pay license fee according to the number of users or usages
qualitative_analysis.justification: Shows usage-based licensing between HQ and local operators in a decentralized SaaS franchise-like model.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Selection of the Proper Revenue and Pricing Model for SaaS
qualitative_analysis.quote: The network operators operate the platform and deliver games to players' set-top boxes or to PCs through their broadband network
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes infrastructure providers as platform operators in gaming-as-a-service delivery.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Service-Centric Business Model in Cloud Environment
qualitative_analysis.quote: The value network class describes social and technical resources transactions and operations within and between organizations towards the organizational framework in value configuration by a cross-organizational analysis perspective
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes value network orchestration in cloud business models emphasizing cross-organizational collaboration.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Designing Viable Multi-sided Data Platforms: The Case of Context-Aware Mobile Travel Applications
qualitative_analysis.quote: it connects multiple groups of actors (i.e., end-users and app developers)
qualitative_analysis.justification: Defines multi-sided platform connecting users and developers with data monetization opportunities.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Designing Viable Multi-sided Data Platforms: The Case of Context-Aware Mobile Travel Applications
qualitative_analysis.quote: Advertisement agencies could offer profile based advertisements to their customers
qualitative_analysis.justification: Shows how platforms monetize user data through targeted advertising based on user profiles.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Economic and business perspectives on smartphones as multi-sided platforms
qualitative_analysis.quote: We interpret mobile operating systems such as iOS and Android as multi-sided platforms that serve a variety of "customers," including consumers (users), handset makers, network operators, app developers, advertisers, and chip manufacturers
qualitative_analysis.justification: Comprehensively describes mobile OS as multi-sided platforms serving six distinct customer groups with complex network effects.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Crushing Candy: The Free-to-Play Game in Its Connective Commodity Form
qualitative_analysis.quote: Companies such as Google, Apple, Facebook, and Amazon operate as platform holders, who set the platform's technological standards and governance model, and mediate between, on the one hand "buyers" (e.g. players), and on the other hand suppliers (e.g. King) or "complementors"
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes platform governance and intermediation role in free-to-play gaming business models.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Crushing Candy: The Free-to-Play Game in Its Connective Commodity Form
qualitative_analysis.quote: For Facebook, companies such as King fulfill an important double role. On the one hand, they generate indirect network effects, adding value to the Facebook platform by offering games, such as Candy Crush Saga, directly on the Facebook website. On the other hand, app developers, such as King, spend millions on advertising, thereby enabling Facebook to commodify its connective properties
qualitative_analysis.justification: Explains the dual value creation mechanism where game developers both enhance platform value and generate advertising revenue for the platform.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Effects of Freemium Strategy in the Mobile App Market: An Empirical Study of Google Play
qualitative_analysis.quote: Google Play allows consumers to share their feedback on these apps through reviews and ratings
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes platform mechanisms for user feedback that influence app discovery and success.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Network Externalities, Incumbent's Competitive Advantage and the Degree of Openness of Software Start-Ups
qualitative_analysis.quote: Firm I sells all goods composing the package in "proprietary" format, while firm E may decide to offer some goods of the package in an "open source" format
qualitative_analysis.justification: Contrasts proprietary vs open source strategies for startups competing against incumbents, considering network externalities.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Clarifying the Value Elements of Business Models for Disturbance Management in Supply Chains
qualitative_analysis.quote: three different types of customer segments for the new service for the management and analysis of transport disturbances can be identified; 1) Owners of the cargo (low value of transported goods), 2) Owners of the cargo (high value of transported goods) and 3) logistic operators
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes customer segmentation based on value delivered, with differentiated pricing for different customer types.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: The Impact of Open Source Software Commercialization on Firm Value
qualitative_analysis.quote: companies collaborate with communities of volunteer developers
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes collaboration between commercial firms and volunteer developer communities in open source ecosystems.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: The Impact of Open Source Software Commercialization on Firm Value
qualitative_analysis.quote: firms that cannot secure access to the underlying technology because of strong patenting activity and the high threat of litigation
qualitative_analysis.justification: Highlights intellectual property challenges as barriers to open source business model adoption.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: The relationship between Open Innovation and Strategy: data-driven analysis of the Mobile Value Services Industry
qualitative_analysis.quote: Device Manufacturer' (Apple, Nokia), 'Mobile Platform Provider' (Google), 'Mobile Network Operator' (Vodafone, TIM), 'Mobile Content & Service Provider' (Buongiorno, Dada)
qualitative_analysis.justification: Maps the complete mobile value services ecosystem with device makers, platform providers, network operators, and content providers.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Open-Source Software Entrepreneurial Business Modelling
qualitative_analysis.quote: Earlier versions of the OSS_EBM framework were introduced in an e-commerce university course targeting both master and doctoral students. Moreover, this framework was presented at two events of early-stage startup business incubators
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes educational and incubation ecosystem support for open source software startups.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Towards a better Understanding of the Dynamics of Platform as a Service Business Models
qualitative_analysis.quote: IT startups are dynamic in their early stages and thus will use new technologies and products compared to companies established before them. Thereby, these early adaptors will help to place the platform within the market
qualitative_analysis.justification: Highlights the role of startup early adopters in establishing PaaS platforms in the market.

qualitative_analysis.article_title: Towards a better Understanding of the Dynamics of Platform as a Service Business Models
qualitative_analysis.quote: Platform modules [1] – applications, services, components, add-ons, extensions, and custom developments – are provided by independent software vendors (ISV)
qualitative_analysis.justification: Describes the modular architecture enabling ISVs to extend platform functionality, creating ecosystem value.
